newsitem.title: USA: US rail freight traffic up from year ago -- AAR.
newsitem.headline: US rail freight traffic up from year ago -- AAR.

text.p: U.S. rail freight traffic rose modestly in the week ended October 19 from the same week a year ago, the Association of American Railroads said Thursday.

AAR said carloads in the week totaled 360,393, up 1.4 percent from 355,529 in the year-ago week. Intermodal traffic, which does not include carloads, stood at 171,779 trailers and containers, a 4.4 percent increase from 164,477 a year ago.
Ton-miles in the week also rose 2.3 percent to 26.9 billion from 26.3 billion last year. A ton-mile is equal to one ton of freight hauled one mile.
Harvey Levine, AAR chief economist, noted that intermodal loadings were having a "continued recovery" from their slowdown in 1995.
Levine also said that grain loadings, which were up 2.5 percent from a year ago, saw "the first increase from year-earlier weekly figures since the week ended April 13."
"There have been predictions of a strong corn crop, and this could be a reflection of that," he added. Grain loadings totaled 28,179 in the October 19 week compared with 27,484 a year ago.

AAR also noted that carloads of farm products other than grain rose 17.8 percent to 2,434 loadings from 2,067 a year ago, while petroleum increased 13.2 percent to 5,791 carloads from 5,114. It also said lumber loadings rose eight percent to 5,282 carloads from 4,890 last year.

The biggest decreases were in primary forest products which fell 11.3 percent to 7,663 carloads from 8,636 a year ago, and in food and kindred products which were down 7.5 percent to 8,572 carloads from 9,272 carloads in the same 1995 week.
In the first 42 weeks of 1996, AAR said ton-miles rose 1.9 percent from the same period last year. Intermodal traffic also rose 1.2 percent, but carloads fell 0.8 percent, AAR said.
